Authors: Zagorska V., Aboltiņš A., Upitis A.
Title: Untraditional solutions for the usage of greenhouse effect
Source title: Vide. Tehnologija. Resursi -  Environment, Technology, Resources
Affiliations: Latvia University of Agriculture, Institute of Mechanics, J.čakstes bulv. 5, Jelgava, LV 3001, Latvia; Latvia University of Agriculture, Research Institute of Agricultural Machinery, 1 Instituta St, Ulbroka, Riga region, LV 29310, Latvia
Authors with affiliations: Zagorska, V., Latvia University of Agriculture, Institute of Mechanics, J.čakstes bulv. 5, Jelgava, LV 3001, Latvia; Aboltiņš, A., Latvia University of Agriculture, Institute of Mechanics, J.čakstes bulv. 5, Jelgava, LV 3001, Latvia; Upitis, A., Latvia University of Agriculture, Research Institute of Agricultural Machinery, 1 Instituta St, Ulbroka, Riga region, LV 29310, Latvia
Abstract: The heat solar energy traditionally is used in greenhouses for ensuring optimal plant vegetation regime in our climatic conditions. Glass verandas built during last centuries at the south side of living houses and summer cottages are appreciated as original use of solar energy. Veranda as light and warm room was used for different household needs and also for social activities. Up-to-date materials and technologies proposes wide spectrum of innovative activities for greenhouses and conservatories. The variable amount of solar energy is possible to smooth out by using accumulation system. In the paper results from vegetable drying experiments are presented. In the research used products - carrots, dry matter of the product at the start 8.5%, chopped product - 9.9%, after desiccation - equilibrium moisture content 10 -11%. The experimental device placed in the room is simulating the processes, which would occur if we use greenhouse for product drying, accordingly making changes in the design of conventional greenhouses by separating drying section from growing section, supplying warm heated in the greenhouse upper layer air from the bottom by forcing it with axial ventilator, and accordingly choosing appropriate accumulation system for energy storage in case when outside air temperature drop occurs.
Author Keywords: Drying; Greenhouses; Heat energy accumulation
Index Keywords: Greenhouse effect; Greenhouses; Heating; Product design; Solar energy; Climatic conditions; Equilibrium moisture contents; Experimental devices; Heat energy; Innovative activities; Materials and technologies; Outside-air temperature; Social activities; Drying

Authors: Miklaševičs Z.
Title: The technological investigations of manufacturing of energy chips
Source title: Vide. Tehnologija. Resursi -  Environment, Technology, Resources
Affiliations: Rezeknes Augstskola, Atbrivošanas aleja 90, Rezekne, LV 4601, Latvia
Authors with affiliations: Miklaševičs, Z., Rezeknes Augstskola, Atbrivošanas aleja 90, Rezekne, LV 4601, Latvia
Abstract: The methodology in Latvia forest industry provide to determine the quality of energy chips only in long- term storage places before selling. Due to the lack of hard empirical data about the quality parameters of energy chips in different phases of manufacturing process, this research paper consists of: - the identification and analyses of the factors that influenced the values of energy chips quality features such as: bulk density, moisture content, ash content, higher and lower heating value according to actual moisture content and per dry mass of the chips; - the methodology for determination the quality parameters of energy chips by analysis the wood moisture content and by choice the method of the manufacturing of energy chips.
Author Keywords: Energy chips; Technological investigations

Title: A battery model for small renewable sources
Source title: Proceedings of the 12th International Scientific Conference Electric Power Engineering 2011, EPE 2011
Affiliations: Brno University of Technology, FEEC, DEE, Technicka 3058/10, 61600 Brno, Czech Republic; Czech Technical University in Prague, FEE, Technicka 2, 16000 Praha 6, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Radil, L., Brno University of Technology, FEEC, DEE, Technicka 3058/10, 61600 Brno, Czech Republic; Mastny, P., Brno University of Technology, FEEC, DEE, Technicka 3058/10, 61600 Brno, Czech Republic; Kyncl, J., Brno University of Technology, FEEC, DEE, Technicka 3058/10, 61600 Brno, Czech Republic, Czech Technical University in Prague, FEE, Technicka 2, 16000 Praha 6, Czech Republic
Abstract: For photovoltaic or others unstable sources are necessary reserve from different basic sources of energy. They have to be faster like gas power plant or batteries. They are able to prevent electric power fluctuations. Authors in the past focused on describing the various technologies that are suitable for this activity. Currently, batteries are the best way for smaller systems. This article therefore deals with the basic mathematical model of battery, which then comes out of a complete system for energy storage in the Czech Republic.

Title: Development of future energy networks and new possibilities for transmission of energy
Source title: Proceedings of the 12th International Scientific Conference Electric Power Engineering 2011, EPE 2011
Affiliations: West Bohemia University in Pilsen, Department of Electric Power System Engineering and Ecology, Univerzitní 26, 306 14 Plzeň, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Mezera, J., West Bohemia University in Pilsen, Department of Electric Power System Engineering and Ecology, Univerzitní 26, 306 14 Plzeň, Czech Republic; Martínek, Z., West Bohemia University in Pilsen, Department of Electric Power System Engineering and Ecology, Univerzitní 26, 306 14 Plzeň, Czech Republic; Kůs, D., West Bohemia University in Pilsen, Department of Electric Power System Engineering and Ecology, Univerzitní 26, 306 14 Plzeň, Czech Republic; Zborník, J., West Bohemia University in Pilsen, Department of Electric Power System Engineering and Ecology, Univerzitní 26, 306 14 Plzeň, Czech Republic
Abstract: Distributed production as well as ever-increasing share of renewable sources energy (especially sun and wind) in power generation will soon lead to the profound changes in transmission and distributing system. Therefore, the most modern methods and analyses used for new case studies of optimal energy sources disregard current structure of these systems. This post represents prospective crucial elements of these future systems.

Authors: Moldrik P., Chvalek R.
Title: Fuel cells reliability in energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the 12th International Scientific Conference Electric Power Engineering 2011, EPE 2011
Affiliations: VŠB - TU Ostrava, Katedra Elektroenergetiky, 17. listopadu 15, 708 33 Ostrava, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Moldrik, P., VŠB - TU Ostrava, Katedra Elektroenergetiky, 17. listopadu 15, 708 33 Ostrava, Czech Republic; Chvalek, R., VŠB - TU Ostrava, Katedra Elektroenergetiky, 17. listopadu 15, 708 33 Ostrava, Czech Republic
Abstract: This paper deals with the utilization of the Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFC) within energy storage system with renewable energy resource (RES). The paper provides a view onto the arrangement and functioning of such energy storage system. Special attention is paid to the fuel cell, which represents the fundamental feature of the said storage system. The paper refers to the structure of PEMFC, its losses and efficiency. The experimental section deals with long-term measurements and definition of the essential indicators of reliability.

Authors: Vourliotakis G., Giannopoulos D., Founti M.
Title: Potentials of Fuel Cells as μ-CHP Systems for Domestic Applications in the Framework of Energy Efficient and Sustainable Districts
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Vourliotakis, G., National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Giannopoulos, D., National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Founti, M., National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece
Abstract: The present work presents an innovative energy production and distribution concept for sustainable and energy efficient refurbished and/or new "energy autonomous" districts exploiting decentralized co-generation coupled with optimized building and district heat storage and distribution networks. Centralized power stations feature a primary energy content-based efficiency of less than 35%. On the other hand, a μ-CHP SOFC (Solid Oxide Fuel Cell) based system has an overall efficiency of up to 80-90%. The present concept is based on dynamic heat exchange between the building(s) (fitted with SOFC based energy units and with improved thermal storage and insulation building systems), the distribution system (optimized piping and district heating) and the consumer (new business and service models), aiming to achieve energy balance at district level. The energy reduction will originate from improved efficiency and cost effective SOFCs, coupled with optimized energy and power distribution networks that will optimally control heat storage at building and/or district level. A micro-grid/heat network arrangement of dispersed μ-CHPs, can lead to significant reduction in power transmission and heat dissipation losses, ensuring direct energy savings (up to 60% reduction in primary energy use and CO2emissions) at both building and district levels.
Author Keywords: Building energy storage; Primary energy savings; SOFC; Thermal distribution network; μ-CHP
Index Keywords: Buildings; Carbon dioxide; Environmental impact; Heat storage; Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC); Building energy; Distribution systems; Energy productions; Overall efficiency; Power distribution network; Primary energy savings; Primary energy use; Thermal distributions; Energy efficiency

Authors: Mercangöz M., Hemrle J., Kaufmann L., Buchter F., Ohler C.
Title: Thermoelectric energy storage with transcritical CO2 cycles
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: ABB Switzerland Ltd, Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, Baden, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Mercangöz, M., ABB Switzerland Ltd, Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, Baden, Sweden; Hemrle, J., ABB Switzerland Ltd, Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, Baden, Sweden; Kaufmann, L., ABB Switzerland Ltd, Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, Baden, Sweden; Buchter, F., ABB Switzerland Ltd, Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, Baden, Sweden; Ohler, C., ABB Switzerland Ltd, Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, Baden, Sweden
Abstract: A novel type of bulk electricity storage - thermoelectric energy storage (TEES) - is presented. The concept is based on heat pump and heat engine technologies utilizing transcritical CO2 cycles, storage of pumped heat in hot water, and ice generation and melting at the cold end of the cycles. The paper first describes the growing need for large scale electrical energy storage and the role of storage in the integration of renewable intermittent generation such as wind energy into the electricity network. The background and a short review on TEES is given and the main principles of (i) reversible heat pumping using vapor compression, (ii) thermal energy storage, and finally (iii) back conversion of thermal energy into electricity via a thermal engine are explained. Following the introduction of TEES as a general concept, the transcritical CO2 based system is presented by providing a description of the thermodynamic cycles and the corresponding operating conditions. Next the overview of an envisioned transcritical TEES plant is given with information on the main equipment including the turbomachines such as compressor and turbine, high pressure plate heat exchangers, and ice storage. Key properties of the proposed transcritical TEES system are then reviewed with an emphasis on energy storage efficiency, scalability, site independence, and minimal environmental impact. Information about the operating characteristics such as start up and standby times and storage duration of the proposed system is also given. The paper is concluded by discussing the future perspectives for the proposed system mainly by focusing on potential technology improvements for the CO2 machines and the storage materials for both hot and cold ends of the system.
Author Keywords: Energy storage; Renewable integration; Thermal energy storage
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Heat pump systems; Heat storage; Storage (materials); Thermal energy; Thermodynamic properties; Vapors; Wind power; Electrical energy storages; Electricity networks; Electricity storages; Energy storage efficiencies; Heat pumps; Operating characteristics; Renewable integration; Thermoelectric energy; Carbon dioxide

Authors: Wikström M., Folkesson A., Alvfors P.
Title: Analysis of the fuel economy improvement potential of ethanol hybrid buses
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Division of Energy Processes, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; Sustainable Solutions, Buses and Coaches, Scania CV AB, Södertälje, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Wikström, M., Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Division of Energy Processes, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; Folkesson, A., Sustainable Solutions, Buses and Coaches, Scania CV AB, Södertälje, Sweden; Alvfors, P., Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Division of Energy Processes, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: With the ambitions to further increase its share of renewable fuels and to reduce the amount of carbon dioxide emissions, local emissions and noise, Stockholm Public Transport (SL) hosted a one-year project to evaluate the performance of ethanol hybrid buses. An important part of the project was the duty cycle tests according to SORT - Standardised on-road tests cycles (developed by the International Association of Public Transport, UITP). The duty cycle tests generated experimental data, on which this paper's discussion is based upon. The purpose of this article is to evaluate the potential of energy-efficiency improving measures on the powertrain. The ethanol hybrid bus is a series hybrid vehicle with regenerative braking. A start/stop software to avoid idling was optional. A bus with similar exterior properties, but with the ethanol internal combustion engine coupled to a conventional automatic gearbox instead of a hybrid powertrain was used as a reference throughout the project. Based on both experimental data and simulations, several measures to increase the overall energy-efficiency may be proposed. Assessed measures to increase the energy-efficiency include size optimization of powertrain components, such as energy storage and electric motor, and internal combustion engine (identified by using Sankey diagrams), adjustment of the super capacitors energy management system and utilisation of engine start/stop functionality. Analysis shows that the size of the energy storage is well attuned if applied as urban transport. It would be possible to downsize the ICE, from approximately 200 kW to approximately 150 kW, without losing substantial performance. Using the start/stop software reduces the fuel consumption with 15 % in the standardized city duty cycle but has the potential for even further fuel economy improvements in real traffic with more idling.
Author Keywords: Energy efficiency; Energy flow analysis; Ethanol hybrid bus; Sankey diagrams; Series hybrid

Authors: Tzivanidis C., Antonopoulos K.A., Kravvaritis E.D.
Title: Numerical evaluation of the degree of phase change materials exploitation in building passive solar heating and cooling
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: National Technical University of Athens (N.T.U.A.), School of Mechanical Engineering, Thermal Engineering Department, Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning Laboratory, Solar Energy Laboratory9, Heroon Polytechniou, Zografou 157 73, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Tzivanidis, C., National Technical University of Athens (N.T.U.A.), School of Mechanical Engineering, Thermal Engineering Department, Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning Laboratory, Solar Energy Laboratory9, Heroon Polytechniou, Zografou 157 73, Athens, Greece; Antonopoulos, K.A., National Technical University of Athens (N.T.U.A.), School of Mechanical Engineering, Thermal Engineering Department, Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning Laboratory, Solar Energy Laboratory9, Heroon Polytechniou, Zografou 157 73, Athens, Greece; Kravvaritis, E.D., National Technical University of Athens (N.T.U.A.), School of Mechanical Engineering, Thermal Engineering Department, Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning Laboratory, Solar Energy Laboratory9, Heroon Polytechniou, Zografou 157 73, Athens, Greece
Abstract: Objective of the present study is to analyze the effects of the parameters involved in passive solar heating and cooling of buildings, using phase change materials (PCM), on the energy saving. The analysis is based on an experimentally documented implicit finite-difference solution of a set of differential equations which describes the transient thermal behavior of buildings. Phase change process is simulated by using the effective thermal capacity model. Various simple thermal capacity functions are suggested, tested and compared to each other along the typical year in the Athens area. The parameters considered include PCM phase change heat, phase change temperature range, PCM location and way of embodiment within building elements, i.e. in the form of pure PCM layers or in mixtures with structural materials. The problem of incomplete PCM phase change, which leads to reduced exploitation of the available PCM storage capacity, is examined. According to our predictions, the use of construction mixtures containing PCM provides, in certain cases, advantages over pure PCM layers embodied within walls. For PCM mass fractions from 0-30%, the energy savings may reach the 80% of the energy saving obtained with pure PCM. A properly designed PCM passive solar system with the appropriate values of PCM thermophysical properties and of the other parameters involved, may obtain yearly energy savings up to 33% under the Athens weather conditions.
Author Keywords: Building heating and cooling; Passive solar systems; Phase change materials

Authors: Morandin M., Maréchal F., Buchter F., Mercangöz M.
Title: Conceptual design of a thermo-electrical energy storage system based on heat integration of thermodynamic cycles - Part B: Studying alternative system configurations
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: LENI - EPFL, Station 9, 1015 Lausanne (CH), Switzerland; ABB Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, 5405 Baden (CH), Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Morandin, M., LENI - EPFL, Station 9, 1015 Lausanne (CH), Switzerland; Maréchal, F., LENI - EPFL, Station 9, 1015 Lausanne (CH), Switzerland; Buchter, F., ABB Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, 5405 Baden (CH), Switzerland; Mercangöz, M., ABB Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, 5405 Baden (CH), Switzerland
Abstract: An innovative energy storage system has been recently proposed by ABB corporate research center. This is a thermo-electrical energy storage (TEES) based on thermodynamic cycles. During charging electricity is converted into thermal energy by means of a heat pump and during discharge a thermal engine converts thermal energy into electricity. In this work a TEES system based on hot water and ice storage and on transcritical CO2 cycles is investigated. In the first part of the paper (part A), a methodology for the conceptual design of a TEES system based on Pinch Analysis tools and a procedure for the heuristic synthesis of the heat exchanger network and of the thermal storage were introduced. The results of thermodynamic optimization of a base case configuration with simple cycle configurations were presented. In this second part of the paper alternative system configurations are investigated. The different configurations based on different cycle topologies are generated starting from the base case configuration and modified through an organized procedure based on component staging, addition of mixer and splitters, addition or substitution of components. Thermodynamic optimizations of the most interesting configurations were carried out assuming isentropic efficiencies of expansion and compression similar to those of commercially available turbo-machinery. Results are compared and discussed here addressing some techno-economical considerations. Maximum round-trip efficiencies of the various configurations are not that different from the maximum efficiency of the base case scenario. Results show that complicating the base case topology of the thermal engine and heat pump cycles does not lead to higher system performance than the base case scenario investigated in part A of this paper.
Author Keywords: Energy storage; Heat integration; Pinch analysis; Synthesis; TEES
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Conceptual design; Efficiency; Energy storage; Engines; Environmental impact; Heat pump systems; Heat storage; Synthesis (chemical); Thermal energy; Topology; Energy storage systems; Heat exchanger network; Heat integration; Isentropic efficiency; Pinch analysis; TEES; Thermodynamic cycle; Thermodynamic optimization; Thermodynamic properties

Authors: Persson J., Westermark M.
Title: Phase change material cool storage in a Swedish passive house
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: Division of Energy Processes, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Persson, J., Division of Energy Processes, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; Westermark, M., Division of Energy Processes, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Passive Houses have gained popularity the last ten years as a way of improving the energy efficiency in the housing stock. During the cold winter in Sweden, external heating are at times needed but a Passive House is limited to a maximum use of 14 W/m2 or around 68 kWh/m2*year for external heating, depending on the heating strategy and the climate zone. The challenge of avoiding external heating during the cold winter climate in Sweden has pushed the design of a Passive House in a direction where problems with excessive temperatures might occur summertime. The aim of this paper is to evaluate a comfort cooling strategy for attaining good indoor climate summertime while maintaining good energy efficiency. The studied strategy is a night cool storage with phase change material. To evaluate this, a Matlab code was used for the analysis of climate files along with the thermodynamical properties of PCM-storages and then used with IDA Indoor Climate for building simulations. The building model is based on an actual Passive House in the district Lambohov in Linköping, Sweden, where continuous logging of temperatures are available. Without comfort cooling the simulations show excessive temperatures summertime which is consistent with the field measurements from the actual house. The results show that the phase change material can be a part of the solution and replace a substantial share of the external cooling when removing excessive temperatures but can not provide sufficient cooling during the hottest part of the summer simulated in this paper.
Author Keywords: Building Simulation; Comfort cooling; Passive House; Phase Change Material
Index Keywords: Energy efficiency; Environmental impact; Houses; Phase change materials; Building simulation; Cooling strategy; External cooling; External heating; Field measurement; Heating strategy; Passive house; Thermodynamical properties; Heating

Authors: Henchoz S., Buchter F., Favrat D., Morandin M., Mercangoez M.
Title: Thermoeconomic analysis of a solar enhanced energy storage concept based on thermodynamic cycles
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: Laboratory for Industrial Energy System, EPFL, Switzerland; ABB Switzerland Ltd, Baden-Dättwil, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Henchoz, S., Laboratory for Industrial Energy System, EPFL, Switzerland; Buchter, F., ABB Switzerland Ltd, Baden-Dättwil, Switzerland; Favrat, D., Laboratory for Industrial Energy System, EPFL, Switzerland; Morandin, M., Laboratory for Industrial Energy System, EPFL, Switzerland; Mercangoez, M., ABB Switzerland Ltd, Baden-Dättwil, Switzerland
Abstract: Large scale energy storage may play an increasingly important role in the power generation and distribution sector, especially when large shares of renewable energies will have to be integrated into the electrical grid. Up to now pumped-hydro is the only technology that has been widely used for that purpose. However the spread of this technology is limited by geographic constraints. In the present work, a particular implementation of the storage concept based on thermodynamic cycles, as introduced by ABB Switzerland ltd. Corporate Research, has been analysed thermoeconomically. This concept can be scaled up to a GWh range of stored energy, and is site independent. The underlying idea is to use electricity to power a heat pump transferring heat from a cold source to a hot source (charging mode), while storing the heat and the cold at both sources. Subsequently the energy that has been stored/removed to/from the hot/cold sources can be used to run a heat engine, hence re-delivering the electricity when it is needed (discharging mode). In the implementation presented here, using the ambient temperature as the hot source for both the heat pump and the heat engine allows taking benefit from daily variations of the atmospheric temperature. Indeed, the heat-pump can operate with a higher Coefficient of Performance (CoP) during the night and the heat-engine at higher efficiency during the day. This results in an effective increase of the ratio between the redelivered electricity (discharge) and the stored electricity (charging), compared to a situation where the hot source of both cycles are at the same temperature. The use of solar collectors is a further way to enhance this ratio by increasing the hot source temperature above the ambient temperature during the day. In charging mode, the system consists in an ammonia based Rankine heat-pump interfaced at the evaporator with a latent heat cold storage, and at the condenser to the ambient through aircoolers. In discharging mode an ammonia based Rankine heat-engine is interfaced at the condenser with the latent heat cold storage, and the evaporator(boiler) of the thermal engine is interfaced with hot water produced by a field of flat plate solar collectors. A steady state multiobjective optimization of a 50 MW power output plant was carried out, with the objectives of minimizing the investment costs, and maximizing the ratio between electricity output and input. Several types of cold storage substances have been implemented in the formulation and two different types of solar collector were investigated. A storage efficiency of 57% at a cost of 1200 USD/kW was calculated for an optimized plant using solar energy. Finally, a computation of the behaviour of the plant along the year was carried out, reaching a yearly availability of 84.4%.
Author Keywords: Energy storage; Heat-engine; Heat-pump; Solar energy; Thermodynamic cycles; Thermoeconomy
Index Keywords: Ammonia; Cold storage; Costs; Energy storage; Engines; Environmental impact; Evaporators; Heat pump systems; Investments; Latent heat; Multiobjective optimization; Pumps; Solar collectors; Solar energy; Temperature; Abb switzerland ltd; Coefficient of Performance; Flat-plate solar collectors; Heat-pump; Hot-source temperature; Thermo-economy; Thermodynamic cycle; Thermoeconomic analysis; Electricity

Authors: Chmielniak T., Lepszy S., Wójcik K.
Title: Analysis of gas turbine combined heat and power system for carbon capture installation of coal fired power plant
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: Silesian University of Technology, Institute of Power Engineering and Turbomachinery, Konarskiego St. 18, Gliwice 41-100, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Chmielniak, T., Silesian University of Technology, Institute of Power Engineering and Turbomachinery, Konarskiego St. 18, Gliwice 41-100, Poland; Lepszy, S., Silesian University of Technology, Institute of Power Engineering and Turbomachinery, Konarskiego St. 18, Gliwice 41-100, Poland; Wójcik, K., Silesian University of Technology, Institute of Power Engineering and Turbomachinery, Konarskiego St. 18, Gliwice 41-100, Poland
Abstract: Chemical absorption is a very effective and nowadays often used method of gas separation in chemical industry. This method is also often taken into account when considering systems of carbon capture from flue gases of coal fired power plants. This process is very energy-intensive and significantly reduces the performance of the power plant. Thus it seems appropriate to seek external sources of heat for the purpose of carbon capture installation. In the paper, the integration of a coal-fired power plant with the gas turbine combined heat and power system for carbon capture and storage (CCS) installation has been analyzed. The parameters of the gas unit, which fully meets the needs of CCS for the 900 MW coal power plant with supercritical parameters, have been determined. In carbon dioxide capture installation aqueous ammonia have been used as a solvent. There have been examined two variants of the gas unit:-natural gas fired gas turbine with water boiler,-natural gas fired gas steam cycle with 1-pressure heat recovery steam generator. The parameters of these analysis have been compared with parameters of power plant working without an external heat source. Specified rate of avoided emissions, and economic analysis of the project have been determined.
Author Keywords: Avoided emission; Chemical absorption; Economic analysis; Gas steam cycle

Authors: Morandin M., Maréchal F., Buchter F., Mercangöz M.
Title: Conceptual design of a thermo-electrical energy storage system based on heat integration of thermodynamic cycles - Part A: Methodology and base case system configuration
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: LENI - EPFL, Station 9, 1015 Lausanne (CH), Switzerland; ABB Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, 5405 Baden (CH), Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Morandin, M., LENI - EPFL, Station 9, 1015 Lausanne (CH), Switzerland; Maréchal, F., LENI - EPFL, Station 9, 1015 Lausanne (CH), Switzerland; Buchter, F., ABB Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, 5405 Baden (CH), Switzerland; Mercangöz, M., ABB Corporate Research, Segelhofstrasse 1K, 5405 Baden (CH), Switzerland
Abstract: Energy storage (ES) is necessary when supply and demand of energy do not occur at the same time. Independently of the scale of the system, this may be the case in which the energy source is randomly available or when it is more convenient to purchase energy outside peak-demand time intervals. The interest in new type of large scale ES (capacity > 1 GJ, nominal power > 1 MW) for the electricity sector is increasing world wide since the sites for building traditional pump-hydro plants are running out. A new concept of ES has been recently proposed by ABB corporate research center. This is a thermo-electrical energy storage (TEES) based on thermodynamic cycles. During charge electricity is converted into thermal energy by means of a heat pump and during discharge a thermal engine converts thermal energy into electricity. In this work a TEES system based on hot water and ice storage and on transcritical CO2 cycles is investigated. In this first part of the paper, a methodology for the conceptual design of a TEES system based Pinch Analysis tools is introduced. A procedure based on the interpretation of the system composite curves was developed for the synthesis of the heat exchanger network and for the design of the storage subsystems. Such heuristic rules were implemented in a code that allows to find the complete system design starting from the intensive cycle parameters only. A thermodynamic optimization of a base case configuration was performed. The results of this first optimization are presented here and discussed with the help of simple statistical tools. A maximum round-trip efficiency of 0.6 was obtained for the base case TEES configuration assuming isentropic efficiencies of expansion and compression similar to those of commercially available turbo-machinery.
Author Keywords: Energy storage; Heat integration; Pinch analysis; Synthesis; TEES
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Conceptual design; Economics; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Machinery; Statistical mechanics; Synthesis (chemical); Thermal energy; Energy storage systems; Heat exchanger network; Heat integration; Isentropic efficiency; Pinch analysis; System configurations; TEES; Thermodynamic optimization; Thermodynamic properties

Authors: Li H., Svendsen S.
Title: Exergy and energy analysis of low temperature district heating network
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: Technical University of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Li, H., Technical University of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark; Svendsen, S., Technical University of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark
Abstract: Low temperature district heating (LTDH) with reduced network supply and return temperature provides better match of the low quality building thermal demand and the low quality waste heat supply. In this paper, an exemplary LTDH network was designed for 30 low energy demand residential houses, which is in line with a pilot project that is carrying out in Denmark with network supply/return temperature at 55°C/25 °C. The consumer domestic hot water (DHW) demand is supplied with a special designed district heating (DH) storage tank. The space heating (SH) demand is supplied with a low temperature radiator. The network thermal and hydraulic conditions were simulated under steady state with an in-house district heating network design and simulation code. Through the simulation, the overall system energetic and exergetic efficiencies were calculated and the exergy losses for the major district heating system components were identified.

Authors: Anagnostopoulos J.S., Papantonis D.E.
Title: Study of pumped storage schemes to support high RES penetration in the electric power system of Greece
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Greece; School of Mechanical Engin, N.T.U.A., Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Anagnostopoulos, J.S., School of Mechanical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Greece; Papantonis, D.E., School of Mechanical Engin, N.T.U.A., Athens, Greece
Abstract: The Large scale penetration of major Renewable Energy Sources (wind and solar) into electric grid systems faces important technical problems and limitations due to adverse effects of fluctuating and intermittent RES production on the stability and reliability of the power system. Energy storage constitutes an effective way to manage excess RES production, and pumped storage is the most suitable and least expensive solution for large storage and power capacities. The present study aims to investigate the performance of a pumped storage unit introduced into a conventional HPP (Hydroelectric Power Plant) in Greece. At first, the plant operation and the electric grid data for a reference period of one year are used to compute the time variation of water inflow into the dam, and to estimate the RES production rejections depending on of the installed power. Next, a pumping station which is powered by the rejected RES production and raises water from a lower reservoir to the upper main reservoir is modelled. The additional hydraulic energy stored in the dam can be reused to produce stable and controllable electricity through the hydroturbines of the plant. Various scenarios concerning the pumping station power rate and feeding program, as well as alternative methods to increase the hydroturbines production were examined. The operation of the combined system is simulated in detail for the above cases and the energy results were obtained and analyzed. Also, an economic evaluation of the pumped storage scheme is carried out based on current financial conditions in Greece. The results showed that a considerable amount of RES production can be stored and exploited to multiply the HPP annual energy production, but the economic viability of such an investment depends on some critical parameters, which were identified. Certain guidelines concerning the optimum sizing and operation strategy of the pumped storage scheme are finally extracted.
Author Keywords: High RES penetration; Hydroelectric power plant; Optimum sizing; Pumped storage; Wind energy rejection
Index Keywords: Electric power systems; Environmental impact; Hydraulic turbines; Hydroelectric power plants; Investments; Pumping plants; Reservoirs (water); Wind power; Annual energy productions; Economic evaluations; High RES penetration; Optimum sizing; Pumped Storage; Renewable energy source; Stability and reliabilities; Wind energy rejections; Digital storage

Title: Solutions for the large scale wind energy integration to the power system
Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Scientific Symposium on Electrical Power Engineering, ELEKTROENERGETIKA 2011

Authors with affiliations: Kádár, P., Dept. of Power Systems, ÓBuda University, Bécsi u. 94., Budapest H-1034, Hungary
Abstract: The present power system structures was not planned and implemented for large scale weather dependent renewable generation. The wind technology is cleared but a lot of problems are caused by the poorly forecasted wind run (e.g. lack of control capacities, expensive control, etc.). There are a lot of rumors why not to use the wind energy but there are many technical solutions that foster it. The paper summarizes the role of the pumped storage plants, hydro plants, sudden stop of wind power plants, the forecast basics. Finally we present solutions that make flexible the network (Search for the non controlled capacities, co-control with gas engines, smart grid, Demand Side Management, online control of the wind towers, Intraday power exchange, etc.). Authors: Deuse J.
Title: Integration of small and micro combined heat and power (CHP) systems into distributed energy systems
Source title: Small and Micro Combined Heat and Power (CHP) Systems: Advanced Design, Performance, Materials and Applications
Affiliations: GDF-SUEZ - Tractebel Engineering, Rue de Corbais 51, B1435 Hévillers, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Deuse, J., GDF-SUEZ - Tractebel Engineering, Rue de Corbais 51, B1435 Hévillers, Belgium
Abstract: During the last decades electrical systems have undergone a transformation, which is still underway and is supposed to lead from the 'vertical integration' model to a fully open electricity market. This process presently overlaps with the development of distributed energy resources (DER) that brings under a single concept electricity generation, storage of energy and demand response, all at small scale. DER development raises a number of issues for the different stakeholders. However, it is obviously an opportunity for new, emerging market players, but it brings also new perspectives for incumbents. Participation of DER in the different energy markets requires the setting up of upgraded structures for aggregating small energy sources. This chapter summarizes why dispersed generation is innovating in the electrical power system context. It shows how distributed generation can represent value for the system and it evaluates the significant economic advantage of being interconnected. It concludes with recommendations to wire companies and to regulatory bodies. © 2011 Woodhead Publishing Limited All rights reserved.

Abstract: The proceedings contain 162 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Fibrous Materials. Authors: Al-Nimma D., Altamemi M.
Title: Modeling and simulation of a Single Phase to Single Phase (SPSP) matrix converter with an input filter and a clamp circuit
Source title: Proceedings - 2011 2nd International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation, ICCIA 2011
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, University of Mosul, Mosul, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: Al-Nimma, D., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Mosul, Mosul, Iraq; Altamemi, M., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Mosul, Mosul, Iraq
Abstract: Matrix converters are direct converters capable of converting an alternative input power to an alternative output power at different voltage and frequency without using intermediate storage devices. This paper presents an analytical study of an SPSP matrix converter topology with four bidirectional switches. This topology with the necessary switching strategy was then modeled and simulated and the results and conclusions gained are presented. The paper proved the ability of achieving direct ac→ac conversion depending to a large extendon the software that governs the operation of the matrix converter. The paper also treated to the design of a certain additional circuits required for matrix convertor operation improvements. Such as an input filter and a clamp circuit required to protect the bidirectional switches of the convertor. These circuits help reducing the spikes in voltage across these switches and improving other factors. The method used to commutate the currents in the converter switches is a four-step method, which contributes to reduce stresses experienced by the switches. Using the adopted circuits and methods suitable for the operation of the matrix convertor, a power factor very near to unity (0.997) leading at the input using an inductive load of (0.1) power factor at the required output frequency and a total harmonic distortion of (1.2%) of the load current have been obtained. © 2011 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power factor; Timing circuits; Topology; Virtual storage; Bidirectional switch; Converter topologies; Different voltages; Intermediate storage; Model and simulation; Operation improvements; Switching strategies; Total harmonic distortion (THD); Matrix converters

Authors: Soeprijanto A., Abdillah M.
Title: Subsynchronous resonance damping using SMES optimized by quantum behaved particle swarm optimization
Source title: 2011 Computation and Communication Technologies: 3rd International Conference on Advances in Computing, Control, and Telecommunication Technologies, ACT 2011 - Computer Science Series
Affiliations: Institut Teknologi Sepuluh Nopember, Department of Electrical Engineering, Surabaya, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Soeprijanto, A., Institut Teknologi Sepuluh Nopember, Department of Electrical Engineering, Surabaya, Indonesia; Abdillah, M., Institut Teknologi Sepuluh Nopember, Department of Electrical Engineering, Surabaya, Indonesia
Abstract: Subsynchronous resonance (SSR) problems appeared due to resonance between the turbine and the series capacitor on transmission line is damped by installing superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit which the parameters are optimized by quantum behaved particle swarm optimization (QPSO). The proposed objective function is comprehensive damping index (CDI) of SSR damping. To accommodate the formation of SSR mode, the method is developed on the nominal plant at Java-Bali 500kV electrical power system. The turbine is modeled in a rather detailed model of four levels. Models of other power system components follow the standard linear model for dynamic stability study.
Author Keywords: CDI; SMES; Subsynchronous resonance (SSR)
Index Keywords: Communication systems; Damping; Electric energy storage; Electric power systems; Particle swarm optimization (PSO); Turbines; CDI; Comprehensive damping index (CDI); Electrical power system; Power system components; Quantum-behaved particle swarm optimization; SMES; Subsynchronous resonance; Superconducting magnetic energy storages; Resonance

Authors: Nacusse M.A., Junco S.J.
Title: Passive Fault Tolerant Control: A Bond Graph approach
Source title: 5th Int. Conference on Integrated Modeling and Analysis in Applied Control and Automation, IMAACA 2011, Held at the International Mediterranean and Latin American Modeling Multiconference, I3M 2011
Affiliations: Departamento de Control, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Ingeniería y Agrimensura, Universidad Nacional de Rosario, Ríobamba 245 Bis, S2000EKE Rosario, Argentina; CONICET - Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Científicas y Técnicas, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Nacusse, M.A., Departamento de Control, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Ingeniería y Agrimensura, Universidad Nacional de Rosario, Ríobamba 245 Bis, S2000EKE Rosario, Argentina, CONICET - Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Científicas y Técnicas, Argentina; Junco, S.J., Departamento de Control, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Ingeniería y Agrimensura, Universidad Nacional de Rosario, Ríobamba 245 Bis, S2000EKE Rosario, Argentina
Abstract: The Passive Fault Tolerant Control (PFTC) approach defines a unique, robust control law able to achieve the control objectives even in the presence of a fault. This work addresses the PFTC problem in the Bond Graph (BG) domain. The control law is obtained using an energy and power shaping method in this domain. At its first step, the method proposes a so called Target Bond Graph (TBG) that expresses the desired closed-loop behaviour, i.e., the control system specifications, in terms of a desired closed-loop storage function and a power dissipation function. The control law is obtained in a subsequent step via BG-prototyping. In order to make it fault-tolerant, this control law is further robustified by using a residual signal obtained from a modified version of the diagnostic bond graph (mDBG) which is created from the TBG. This results in a closedloop behavior under faults that it asymptotically equivalent to the faultless case.
Author Keywords: Bond graph; Diagnostic bond graph; Energy and power shaping; Passive fault tolerant control
Index Keywords: Robust control; Specifications; Bond graph; Closed-loop behavior; Control objectives; Dissipation functions; Energy and power shaping; Fault tolerant control; Storage function; System specification; Graph theory

Authors: Dobre C.
Title: A simulation study of data processing activities in CMS physics analysis
Source title: ESM 2011 - 2011 European Simulation and Modelling Conference: Modelling and Simulation 2011
Affiliations: University POLITEHNICA of Bucharest, Spl. Independentei, 313, Bucharest, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Dobre, C., University POLITEHNICA of Bucharest, Spl. Independentei, 313, Bucharest, Romania
Abstract: The scale, complexity and worldwide geographical spread of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) computing and data analysis problems are unprecedented in scientific research. The complexity of processing and accessing this data is increased substantially by the size and global span of the major experiments, combined with the limited wide area network bandwidth available. This paper discusses the latest generation of the MONARC (MOdels of Networked Analysis at Regional Centers) simulation framework, as a design and modeling tool for large scale distributed systems applied to High-Energy Physics (HEP) experiments. We present a simulation study designed to evaluate the capabilities of the current real-world distributed infrastructures deployed to support existing LHC physics analysis processes and the means by which the experiments bands together to meet the technical challenges posed by the storage, access and computing requirements of LHC data analysis. The Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) experiment, in particular, uses a general-purpose detector to investigate a wide range of physics. We present a simulation study designed to evaluate the capability of its underlying distributed processing infrastructure to support the physics analysis processes. The results, made possible by the MONARC's model, demonstrate that the LHC infrastructures are well suited to support the data processes envisioned by the CMS computing model. ©2011 EUROSIS-ETI.
Author Keywords: CMS; Evaluation; Large scale distributed systems; LHC experiments; Modeling and simulation
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Data processing; Digital storage; Distributed computer systems; Experiments; High energy physics; Modal analysis; CMS; Evaluation; Large-scale distributed system; LHC experiments; Model and simulation; Solenoids

Authors: Mackenzie K.J.D.
Title: Inorganic polymers for environmental protection applications
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: MacDiarmid Institute for Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology, School of Chemical and Physical Sciences, Victoria University of Wellington, PO Box 600, Wellington, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Mackenzie, K.J.D., MacDiarmid Institute for Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology, School of Chemical and Physical Sciences, Victoria University of Wellington, PO Box 600, Wellington, New Zealand
Abstract: Aluminosilicate inorganic polymers have been proposed as low-energy cements since, unlike Portland cement, their production does not require high temperatures or generate large quantities of greenhouse gases. Other environmental protection applications for inorganic polymers are to encapsulate hazardous mining or radioactive wastes for safe long-term storage and as fireproof components for buildings and vehicles. However, newly developed methods for synthesising these materials have opened up the possibility of other novel environmental protection applications. These include porous cladding material for passive cooling of buildings, cost-effective exchange materials for removing heavy metals from wastewater, bacteriocidal materials for purifying polluted drinking water and materials for photodegrading hazardous organic environmental pollutants. The nature and synthesis of inorganic polymers for these environmental applications will be discussed here. © 2011 Ceramic Society of Japan.
Index Keywords: Ceramic materials; Cladding (coating); Environmental protection; Fireproofing; Greenhouse gases; Heavy metals; Inorganic polymers; Portland cement; Purification; Radioactive wastes; Wastewater treatment; Water pollution; Aluminosilicate inorganic polymers; Bacteriocidal; Cladding material; Environmental applications; High temperature; Long-term storage; Organic environmental pollutants; Passive cooling; Chemicals removal (water treatment)

Authors: Isupov A.Yu., Kovtun V.E., Foshchan A.G.
Title: The UNIX-based data acquisition system for multichannel nuclear physics setups
Source title: 3rd International Conference on Current Problems in Nuclear Physics and Atomic Energy, NPAE 2010 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Moscow Region, Russian Federation; V. N. Karazin Kharkiv National University, Kharkiv, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Isupov, A.Yu., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Moscow Region, Russian Federation; Kovtun, V.E., V. N. Karazin Kharkiv National University, Kharkiv, Ukraine; Foshchan, A.G., V. N. Karazin Kharkiv National University, Kharkiv, Ukraine
Abstract: The data acquisition system (DAQ) for the Tandem setup (INR NASU) is proposed on base of the ngdp framework under the freely distributed UNIX-like operating system (OS) FreeBSD. The ngdp framework provides the software modules to organize an experimental data streams locally and remotely avoiding the intermediate data storages on the slow medii. The CAMAC subsystem is implemented on base of the camac package (DLNP JINR) using the kh(4) driver for the CC02 crate controller (PTP KhNU). The online visualization is based on the data event-by-event representation for the ROOT package. Such data could be feeded for more than one r2h(1) histogram servers, each of them is able to conversate with more than one histGUI(1) clients. This client depends on neither DAQ nor ngdp libraries so can be compiled under any OS equipped by the ROOT package.
Index Keywords: Data visualization; Nuclear energy; UNIX; Crate controllers; Data acquisition system; Data storage; Data stream; FreeBSD; Multichannel; Online visualizations; Software modules; Nuclear physics

Authors: Surridge A.D., Cloete M., Lloyd P.J.
Title: The Geological Storage of Carbon Dioxide and Disposal of Nuclear Waste in South Africa
Affiliations: South African National Energy Research Institute, 158 Jan Smuts Ave, Sandton, South Africa; Council for Geoscience, 280 Pretoria St, Pretoria, South Africa; Cape Peninsula University of Technology, Symphony Way, Cape Town, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Surridge, A.D., South African National Energy Research Institute, 158 Jan Smuts Ave, Sandton, South Africa; Cloete, M., Council for Geoscience, 280 Pretoria St, Pretoria, South Africa; Lloyd, P.J., Cape Peninsula University of Technology, Symphony Way, Cape Town, South Africa
Abstract: South Africa has a coal-based energy economy, and the use of coal is likely to increase as new coal-fired electricity generation stations and coal-to-liquids plants are built. This situation has been exacerbated by the decision of the ­electricity utility to delay the construction of further nuclear-powered electricity generation stations. Notwithstanding the introduction of renewable energies and energy efficiency measures, the use of fossil fuels is therefore expected to increase. At the South African Climate Change Summit held during March 2009, it was announced that South Africa will increase its carbon dioxide emissions until 2020–2025, plateau for 10 years, and thereafter decrease emissions in real terms. Carbon dioxide capture and storage is being investigated as a measure to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions: a Centre for Carbon Capture and Storage was established on 30 March 2009. Preliminary studies have already indicated some potential, and the completion of a carbon geological storage atlas by mid-2010 is expected to result in more accurate information. Presently South Africa has one nuclear-powered electricity generation station which provides a mere 2.8% of primary energy supply; further stations have been postponed. Currently, high-level radioactive waste is stored on-site at nuclear installations. Low- and ­intermediate-level waste is buried in a remote, desert-like location. The Government is undertaking an investigation into the handling and final disposal of nuclear waste to cater for current and future nuclear installations. An institute that will manage radioactive waste on a national basis is the subject of the National Radioactive Waste Disposal Institute Act, 2008 (No. 53 of 2008) that was gazetted on 9 January 2009. Separate institutions address carbon dioxide storage and radioactive waste, and currently there is little interaction between them. This chapter discusses the status of activities regarding carbon capture and storage and radioactive waste disposal in South Africa. © 2011, Springer Science+Business Media B.V.
Author Keywords: Carbon capture and storage; Carbon storage ­geological atlas; Nuclear waste; South Africa

Title: Passive fault tolerant control: A bond graph approach
Source title: International Conference on Integrated Modeling and Analysis in Applied Control and Automation

Authors: Lee, Cho
Title: Handbook of sustainable energy
Authors with affiliations: Lee; Cho
Abstract: Sustainable energy is the provision of energy such that it meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their needs. A broader interpretation may allow inclusion of fossil fuels and nuclear fission as transitional sources while technology develops, as long as new sources are developed for future generations to use. A narrower interpretation includes only energy sources which are not expected to be depleted in a time frame relevant to the human race. Sustainable energy sources are most often regarded as including all renewable sources, such as biofuels, solar power, wind power, wave power, geothermal power and tidal power. It usually also includes technologies that improve energy efficiency. This new and important handbook gathers the latest research from around the globe in the study of sustainable energy and highlights such topics as: monitoring sustainable energy development; methane; energy and territory; biodiesel production; electrochemical hydrogen storage; environmental policies in an electricity sector and others. © 2010 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Kovalevskii A.A., Strogova A.S., Labunov V.A., Shevchenok A.A.
Title: Nano- and microstructural silicon powders in the synthesis and storage of hydrogen
Source title: Nanopowders and Nanocoatings: Production, Properties and Applications
Affiliations: Institute of Applied Mathematics and Mechanics, Donetsk, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Kovalevskii, A.A., Institute of Applied Mathematics and Mechanics, Donetsk, Ukraine; Strogova, A.S., Institute of Applied Mathematics and Mechanics, Donetsk, Ukraine; Labunov, V.A., Institute of Applied Mathematics and Mechanics, Donetsk, Ukraine; Shevchenok, A.A., Institute of Applied Mathematics and Mechanics, Donetsk, Ukraine
Abstract: Complex use of products of interaction of MNS SP with water, utilization of heat and effective functioning of power cycle on the basis of nanostructural powder of silicon is the real technology of gaseous hydrogen for hydrogen energy of the nearest future. Application of MNS SP gives undeniable advantages: simple and without expenses of energy from outside technology of hydrogen production in the result of water decomposition: the necessity in storage and transportation of gasiform hydrogen disappears, which promotes fire- and explosionproof of this fragment of hydrogen energy substantially. In the process of the industrial production of nanopowders of silicon, including for other areas of their application their prime price will be reduced some times of their value. The application of MNS SP in the mobile small sources of hydrogen is already expedient. © 2010 Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Joshi S.C.
Title: Gelation of MC and HPMC in various media
Source title: Handbook of Hydrogels: Properties, Preparation & Applications
Affiliations: School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639 798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Joshi, S.C., School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639 798, Singapore
Abstract: Substitutions in cellulose, which is insoluble in water, methyl in methylcellulose (MC) and hydroxypropyl-methyl groups in hydroxypropyl methylcellulose (HPMC) allow them to dissolve in aqueous medium at room temperature, gel upon heating, and revert back to the solution state upon cooling. This thermoreversible behavior of MC and HPMC is affected by their properties and concentration in the solvent media, the nature of additives, and thermal environment they are exposed to. Research in understanding the mechanism of the sol-gel transition process has gained considerable interest because of a variety of applications of MC and HPMC as thickeners, binders or matrices in pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and food industries. This chapter includes investigations on the changes brought about by thermal energy in the specific heat capacity, the storage (G') and viscous (G") modulii, and the turbidity of the hydrogels. The effects of salt additives are discussed. Differences associated with initial solvent temperature, solvent state, solvent isotopes, temperature history, thermal conditions and the temperature range are highlighted. Reasons for hysteresis seen during the heating and cooling processes are identified and discussed. Mathematical models established for describing sol-gel transitions and related mechanisms are presented. The nature of the mechanisms along with the underlying influence of thermal energy and various media additives are explained. Parameters such as degree of gelation and degelation, the water entrapment point and the gel index are introduced and discussed. The details of the thermodynamics involved and the gelation kinetics are included. The findings highlighted shortcomings in the earlier definition of the gel point as the cross-over point on the G' and G" plots. The detailed interpretation of various molecule level interactions unfolded the sol-gel mechanisms and the influence of several factors. The obtained test data and the established mathematical models are expected to serve as the guides for customizing various applications of MC and HPMC hydrogels. © 2009 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Elmegaard B., Brix W.
Title: Efficiency of compressed air energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems, ECOS 2011
Affiliations: DTU Technical University of Denmark, Department of Mechanical Engineering, 2800 Kgs. Lyngby, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Elmegaard, B., DTU Technical University of Denmark, Department of Mechanical Engineering, 2800 Kgs. Lyngby, Denmark; Brix, W., DTU Technical University of Denmark, Department of Mechanical Engineering, 2800 Kgs. Lyngby, Denmark
Abstract: The simplest type of a Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) facility would be an adiabatic process consisting only of a compressor, a storage and a turbine, compressing air into a container when storing and expanding when producing. This type of CAES would be adiabatic and would if the machines were reversible have a storage efficiency of 100%. However, due to the specific capacity of the storage and the construction materials the air is cooled during and after compression in practice, making the CAES process diabatic. The cooling involves exergy losses and thus lowers the efficiency of the storage significantly. The efficiency of CAES as an electricity storage may be defined in several ways, we discuss these and find that the exergetic efficiency of compression, storage and production together determine the efficiency of CAES. In the paper we find that the efficiency of the practical CAES electricity storage is 25-45% and thus has a quite low efficiency, which is close to the efficiency of the simple diabatic CAES-process. Adiabatic CAES would reach significantly higher storage efficiency about 70-80%.
Author Keywords: Compressed air energy storage; Electricity storage; Exergy analysis
Index Keywords: Compressed air; Electric energy storage; Environmental impact; Exergy; Pressure vessels; Adiabatic process; Compressed air energy storage; Electricity storages; Exergetic efficiency; Exergy Analysis; Exergy loss; Specific capacities; Storage efficiency; Efficiency

Authors: Holt M.
Title: Nuclear waste disposal: Alternatives to Yucca Mountain
Source title: U.S. Energy and the Environment: An Overview and Comparative Analysis
Authors with affiliations: Holt, M.
Abstract: Congress designated Yucca Mountain, NV, as the nation's sole candidate site for a permanent high-level nuclear waste repository in 1987, following years of controversy over the site-selection process. Over the strenuous objections of the State of Nevada, the Department of Energy (DOE) submitted a license application for the proposed Yucca Mountain repository in June 2008 to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). During the 2008 election campaign, now-President Obama lent support to Nevada's fight against the repository, contending in an issue statement that he and now-Vice President Biden "do not believe that Yucca Mountain is a suitable site." Under the current nuclear waste program, DOE hopes to begin transporting spent nuclear fuel and other highly radioactive waste to Yucca Mountain by 2020. That schedule is 22 years beyond the 1998 deadline established by the Nuclear Waste Policy Act (NWPA). Because U.S. nuclear power plants will continue to generate nuclear waste after a repository opens, DOE estimates that all waste could not be removed from existing reactors until about 2066 even under the current Yucca Mountain schedule. Not all the projected waste could be disposed of at Yucca Mountain, however, unless NWPA's current limit on the repository's capacity is increased. If the Obama Administration decides to halt the Yucca Mountain project, it has a variety of tools available to implement that policy. Although the President cannot directly affect NRC proceedings, the Secretary of Energy could withdraw the Yucca Mountain license application under NRC rules. The President could also urge Congress to cut or eliminate funding for the Yucca Mountain project, and propose legislation to restructure the nuclear waste program. Abandonment of Yucca Mountain would probably further delay the federal government's removal of nuclear waste from reactor sites and therefore increase the government's liabilities for missing the NWPA deadline. DOE estimates that such liabilities will reach "11 billion even if Yucca Mountain opens as currently planned. DOE's agreements with states to remove defenserelated high-level waste could also be affected. If the Yucca Mountain project were halted without a clear alternative path for waste management, the licensing of proposed new nuclear power plants could be affected as well. NRC has determined that waste can be safely stored at reactor sites for at least 30 years after a reactor shuts down and is proposing to extend that period to 60 years. While that proposal would allow at least 100 years for waste to remain at reactor sites (including a 40-year reactor operating period), NRC's policy is that new reactors should not be licensed without "reasonable confidence that the wastes can and will in due course be disposed of safely." Current law provides no alternative repository site to Yucca Mountain, and it does not authorize DOE to open temporary storage facilities without a permanent repository in operation. Without congressional action, therefore, the default alternative to Yucca Mountain would be indefinite on- site storage of nuclear waste at reactor sites and other nuclear facilities. Private central storage facilities can also be licensed under current law; such a facility has been licensed in Utah but its operation has been blocked by the Department of the Interior. Congress has considered legislation repeatedly since the mid-1990s to authorize a federal interim storage facility for nuclear waste but none has been enacted. Reprocessing of spent fuel could reduce waste volumes and long-term toxicity, but such facilities are costly and raise concerns about the separation of plutonium that could be used in nuclear weapons. Storage and reprocessing would still eventually require a permanent repository, and a search for a new repository site would need to avoid the obstacles that have hampered previous U.S. efforts. © 2010 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. Authors: Grabara J.K., Kapuściński J., Kot S.
Title: Distribution of electricity in the context of meteorological phenomena
Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Scientific Symposium on Electrical Power Engineering, ELEKTROENERGETIKA 2011
Affiliations: Management Faculty, Czestochowa University of Technology, Czestochowa, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Grabara, J.K., Management Faculty, Czestochowa University of Technology, Czestochowa, Poland; Kapuściński, J., Management Faculty, Czestochowa University of Technology, Czestochowa, Poland; Kot, S., Management Faculty, Czestochowa University of Technology, Czestochowa, Poland
Abstract: Distribution of electricity is a specific process, because of energy storage difficulty on a larger scale, the continuity of electricity supply depends on efficiency of distribution network operation. Assurance of suitable conditions of energy transfer infrastructure through maintenance and repair is a crucial element of energy supply continuity. However, there is a group of factors caused by weather phenomena, those negative effects on the grid have not yet been included in the larger consideration and they have not been taken to determine their characteristics, dynamics and predict the effects on the grid. This article discusses the major meteorological phenomena (rain, hoar frost, floods, cyclones) having the biggest impact on the electricity grid failures and power outages in the climatic conditions in Poland. Based on the chosen examples of there are presented reasons for the formation of above mentioned meteorological phenomena with their volatility and the consequences for the grid. The authors hope that a better understanding of meteorological phenomena that cause the most negative effects on the electricity grid allow for better preparing for the removal of a grid failure as an effect of those meteorological phenomena and before all of their prevention through better planning of infrastructure location and more suitable design in relation to meteorological conditions in the considered area. Technical University of Košice © 2011.

Authors: Mitra-Delmotte G.
Title: Magnetic minerals, life, and its emergence
Affiliations: 39 Cite de l'Ocean, Montgaillard, St.Denis 97400, Reunion
Authors with affiliations: Mitra-Delmotte, G., 39 Cite de l'Ocean, Montgaillard, St.Denis 97400, Reunion
Abstract: Entropy/information accounting has a central role in biology as evidenced from the correspondence between the fundamental Fisher's theorem of natural selection and the fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT). But what scaffold with lowered kinetic barriers for hosting webs of metabolic reaction cycles [c.f. Cairns-Smith 1985] could have allowed such tight coupling of energy flow and information, proposed by Morowitz [1955] and extended by a scaling analysis towards (generative, computation-enabling) reversible transformations [Smith 2008b], given that homogeneous energy sources sustain life's self-organization (without external constraints)? Consider a network of interactions where interchanges between environmental fluctuations and system-entropy (extensible to the reversible limit) could be driven and controlled by a permeating deeper level source whose existence instantly registers even before an empirical check. Indeed, the potential of magnetic nano-particles embodying spins for accessing a range of possibilities-from cooperative aspects, asymmetric dynamics to quantum phenomena-- underlies the quest for magnetic (H)-field driven matter as a candidate for life's fountainhead. Here an H-field is the connecting link between the susceptibility-to-field variations and the correlators between interacting spins via FDT, for producing a dissipatively ordered state by harnessing fluctuations. Although differing in mechanism from the familiar quenched spin-glass dynamics (resembling an inhomogeneous frustrated bio-network), the ferrofluid-based associative-network for pattern-storage via field variations [Palm and Korenivski 2009], shows the potential of magnetic dipolar interactions for meeting Anderson's [1983] diversity-cum-stability criteria for origins-oflife, as in his spin glass model (large numbers of degenerate states and slow relaxation between them). As a plausible scenario for materializing these requirements, we have proposed that magnetic rocks could have provided a moderate external H-field, enabling accretion of magnetic nano-particles on the Hadean Ocean Floor, analogous to field- induced structures observed in magnetite-based ferrofluids. To that end, a natural candidate is greigite (Fe3S4) that forms in the alkaline seepage site hydrothermal mound scenario of Russell et al [2005], showing how metabolites could have accumulated in membranous inorganic compartments. Here, catalytic greigite reveals the link to the geochemical origins of life's emergence owing to its close resemblance to iron-sulphur clusters in enzymes (considered ancient). But under today's globally oxygenic conditions it occurs rarely, which interestingly contrasts with its close cousin magnetite appearing across all kingdoms of biology. Local sources, like accumulated magnetized meteoritic matter, could have provided the required field ~4.2-4.3 Gya when life is thought to have been initiated. This was further reinforced by magnetite forming as an alteration product, immediately beneath the mound. © 2011 Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Associative storage; Computation theory; Correlators; Entropy; Glass; Iron compounds; Magnetic fluids; Magnetic storage; Magnetism; Magnetite; Metabolites; Spin dynamics; Spin glass; Stability criteria; Sulfur compounds; Associative network; Cooperative aspects; Environmental fluctuations; External constraints; Fluctuation-dissipation theorem; Iron-sulphur clusters; Magnetic dipolar interactions; Reversible transformation; Magnetic nanoparticles

Authors: Gilmore P.L.
Title: Lipids: Categories, biological functions and metabolism, nutrition and health
Source title: Lipids: Categories, Biological Functions and Metabolism, Nutrition and Health
Authors with affiliations: Gilmore, P.L.
Abstract: The main biological function of lipids include energy storage, as structural components of cell membranes, and as important signaling molecules. Lipids are a major source of energy in the body and supply essential lipid-soluble vitamins and polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) that are required in relatively high amounts during growth and life. Lipids affect the composition of membrane structures and modulate membrane functions as well as the functional development of the central nervous system. This book presents and discusses topical data on lipids including: the lipid composition of erythrocytes in cardiovascular and hepatobiliary disease; the correlation of dietary fat, fat composition and fatty acids on human nutrition; flax lipids; Vitamin E lipids with important antioxidant benefits; omega-3 fatty acids in neurochemistry; and others. © 2011 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Hazami M., Kooli S., Lazaar M., Farhat A.H., Belghith A.
Title: Passive and available house air-conditioning by exploiting renewable energy sources
Source title: Air Conditioning Systems: Performance, Environment and Energy Factors
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Maîtrise des Technologies de l'Energie, Technopôle de Borj, Cedria Hammam-Lif BP 95, Tunisia; Faculté des Sciences de Tunis, Campus, El belvédère Tunis-1060, Tunisia
Authors with affiliations: Hazami, M., Laboratoire de Maîtrise des Technologies de l'Energie, Technopôle de Borj, Cedria Hammam-Lif BP 95, Tunisia; Kooli, S., Laboratoire de Maîtrise des Technologies de l'Energie, Technopôle de Borj, Cedria Hammam-Lif BP 95, Tunisia; Lazaar, M., Laboratoire de Maîtrise des Technologies de l'Energie, Technopôle de Borj, Cedria Hammam-Lif BP 95, Tunisia; Farhat, A.H., Laboratoire de Maîtrise des Technologies de l'Energie, Technopôle de Borj, Cedria Hammam-Lif BP 95, Tunisia; Belghith, A., Faculté des Sciences de Tunis, Campus, El belvédère Tunis-1060, Tunisia
Abstract: In Tunisia, the buildings'space heating sector represents a major part of the totalenergy consumption budget. These issues have been increasingly prominent concernssince the energy crisis. Hence, interest has been growing to adopt renewable energies asviable sources of energy that offer a wide range of exceptional benefits for present andfuture applications, with an important degree of promise especially in the buildingssector. However, the management of the renewable energy sources for space airheating/cooling is usually not economically feasible compared with the traditionalcarriers. In this chapter, we present a passive energy system, called an air-conditioningcupboard which exploits renewable energies [hot water supplied from a solar collector(40-50°C) and cold groundwater (19°C)] as thermal sources, conceived and tested in ourlaboratory (LMTE, Tunisia).To evaluate the air-conditioning cupboard efficiency, indoor experiments werecarried out under varied Tunisian environmental conditions for several days. Resultsshow that the air-heating system has a good thermal effectiveness (80 %). It permits us tomaintain the temperature inside the experimented room at the range of [24-27°C] duringthe cold months and [20-23°C] during hot months. A theoretical model is employed forthe sizing of the air-conditioning cupboard to obtain the required temperature values.This model allows also the determination of the air-cupboard conditioning thermalperformances. © 2010 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.
